gmmaker > createBodyOptions

createBodyOptions 

interface createBodyOptions

Summary

Properties from createBodyOptions

body
bodyDef

The body to be created.
fixture[]
fixtureDefs

The fixtures that will be making up the body, from farthest to nearest.
shape[]
shapeDefs

The shapes that make up each fixture. Each shape corresponds to their respective item; the first shape defined here corresponds to the first fixture, the second to the second, and so on.
number
viewOrder

Indicates where in game.state.physics.bro the body ID should be placed.

Public Properties

bodyDef gmm.d.ts:1504 
bodyDef: body

body

The body to be created.

It's not necessary to specify every property of the body here, any missing properties will be replaced with default values, so you can remove property definitions for stuff you don't need. For example: velocity, drag, fixed rotation, apply forces, and some others are not used on static bodies, so you can remove those when creating one.

fixtureDefs gmm.d.ts:1514 
fixtureDefs: fixture[]

fixture[]

The fixtures that will be making up the body, from farthest to nearest.

It's not necessary to specify every property of every fixture here, any missing properties will be replaced with default values, so you can remove property definitions for stuff you don't need. For example: physical properties, as well as death, no grapple and inner grapple are not used in a no-physics fixture, so you can remove those when defining one.

shapeDefs gmm.d.ts:1524 
shapeDefs: shape[]

shape[]

The shapes that make up each fixture. Each shape corresponds to their respective item; the first shape defined here corresponds to the first fixture, the second to the second, and so on.

It's not necessary to specify every property of every shape here, any missing properties will be replaced with default values, so you can remove property definitions for stuff you don't need to specify right now.

viewOrder gmm.d.ts:1494 
viewOrder: number

number

Indicates where in game.state.physics.bro the body ID should be placed.

In other words, it indicates the layer at which the body will be drawn, where the layer with the biggest number is the farthest layer, and the layer with the smallest number (down to 0) is the nearest layer.

If you don't specify this, the body will be placed at the nearest layer (0).
